Questions.Question: Who said, 'The best thing to hold onto in life is each other'?
Questions.Explanation: Audrey Hepburn, the renowned actress, and humanitarian delivered this timeless quote, emphasizing the value of love and relationships.

Questions.Question: Which famous playwright wrote, 'The course of true love never did run smooth'?
Questions.Explanation: This line is from Shakespeare's comedic play 'A Midsummer Night's Dream,' exploring the complexities of love.

Questions.Question: Who said, 'Love yourself first and everything else falls into line'?
Questions.Explanation: Lucille Ball, a pioneering actress and comedian, spoke these empowering words about self-love and its impact on life.

Questions.Question: Which romantic poet penned the line, 'I have waited for this opportunity for more than 40 years to arrive'?
Questions.Explanation: This quote stems from John Keats' letter to Fanny Brawne, expressing his enduring affection and longing.

Questions.Question: Who stated, 'The best and most beautiful things in the world cannot be seen or even touched - they must be felt with the heart'?
Questions.Explanation: Helen Keller, a symbol of determination, communicated this profound sentiment, underscoring the intangible nature of genuine beauty and love.

Questions.Question: Which famous poet advocated, 'If you have a heart that has never been touched with love, then you have never known what it is to live'?
Questions.Explanation: Langston Hughes, a celebrated figure of the Harlem Renaissance, highlighted the transformative power of love on one's existence.

Questions.Question: Who claimed, 'The greatest happiness of life is the conviction that we are loved - loved for ourselves, or rather, loved in spite of ourselves'?
Questions.Explanation: Victor Hugo, eminent author of 'Les Misérables,' articulated this poignant perception, focusing on the profound impact of unconditional love on one's well-being.

Questions.Question: Which iconic actress remarked, 'In real love you want the other person's good. In romantic love, you want the other person'?
Questions.Explanation: Margaret Anderson, an influential figure in 20th-century literature, depicted the distinction between altruistic love and possessive romantic infatuation in this statement.

Questions.Question: Who wrote, 'Love is like the wind, you can't see it but you can feel it'?
Questions.Explanation: Nicholas Sparks, the renowned author of romantic novels, communicated this evocative analogy, representing love's intangible yet powerful nature.

Questions.Question: Which philosopher asserted, 'The goal of life is living in agreement with nature'?
Questions.Explanation: Zeno of Citium, the founder of Stoicism, advocated for aligning with nature's will to attain inner peace and tranquility.

Questions.Question: Who stated, 'A simple 'I love you' means more than money'?
Questions.Explanation: Frank Sinatra, the legendary singer and actor, emphasized the profound emotional significance of expressing love over material wealth.

Questions.Question: Which renowned novelist professed, 'You don't love someone for their looks, or their clothes, or for their fancy car, but because they sing a song only you can hear'?
Questions.Explanation: Oscar Wilde, the flamboyant Irish writer, artistically depicted the depth of intimate connection and understanding in romantic relationships with this metaphorical statement.

Questions.Question: Who proclaimed, 'The only thing we never get enough of is love; and the only thing we never give enough of is love'?
Questions.Explanation: Henry Miller, a provocative and influential writer, conveyed the perpetual yearning for and scarcity of love in human experience in this introspective observation.

Questions.Question: Which iconic actress and singer emphasized, 'Love is a promise, love is a souvenir, once given never forgotten, never let it disappear'?
Questions.Explanation: John Lennon, the visionary musician and activist, reflected on love's enduring nature and its lasting impact on individuals in this profound statement.

Questions.Question: Who articulated the thought, 'Romance is the glamour which turns the dust of everyday life into a golden haze'?
Questions.Explanation: Elinor Glyn, a prominent British romance novelist, metaphorically celebrated romance as an embellishing force that elevates ordinary existence into something extraordinary.

Questions.Question: Which writer expressed, 'Love is an endless act of forgiveness. Forgiveness is the economy of the heart. Love and forgiveness are indivisible'?
Questions.Explanation: Fulton J. Sheen, an influential Catholic bishop, poignantly interconnected love and forgiveness, illustrating the reciprocally transformative nature of both sentiments.

Questions.Question: Who famously said, 'I have become my own version of an optimist. If I can't make it through one door, I'll go through another door - or I'll make a door. Something terrific will come no matter how dark the present'?
Questions.Explanation: Rabindranath Tagore, the Nobel Prize-winning poet, artistically conveyed his resilient and hopeful outlook on life, encapsulating the essence of optimism and perseverance in love.

Questions.Question: Which Nobel Prize-winning author wrote, 'One word frees us of all the weight and pain in life. That word is love'?
Questions.Explanation: Sophocles, the ancient Greek tragedian, distilled the liberating and transcendent power of love in this timeless aphorism, accentuating its transformative effect on human existence.

Questions.Question: Who philosophically suggested, 'We come to love not by finding a perfect person, but by learning to see an imperfect person perfectly'?
Questions.Explanation: Samuel Richardson, the pioneering novelist, encapsulated the profound nature of love, rooted in acceptance and appreciation of imperfections, through this insightful statement.

Questions.Question: Which celebrated feminist author asserted, 'Love makes your soul crawl out from its hiding place'?
Questions.Explanation: Zora Neale Hurston, a significant figure of the Harlem Renaissance, used vivid imagery to portray love's transformative and liberating influence on the human spirit in this statement.
